1425565_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, or GAAP.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	We base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P7_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P7_S4	We have identified the following to be critical accounting policies whose application have a material impact on our reported results of operations, and which involve a higher degree of complexity, as they require us to make judgments and estimates about matters that are inherently uncertain.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue consists primarily of solar energy system installation fees.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	We recognize revenue from fixed price contracts using either the completed or percentage-of-completion method, based on the size of the energy system installation.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	As a result of a recent business acquisition (see Note 3.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	Mergers and Acquisitions), we slightly modified our method of applying revenue recognition for fixed price contracts in that we now recognize revenue from energy system installations of less than 100 kilowatts, or kW, when the installation is substantially complete, while we recognize revenue from energy system installations equal to or greater than 100 kW on a percentage-of-completion basis, measured by the percentage of contract costs incurred to date to total estimated costs for each contract.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	Allowances for Doubtful Accounts We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	We make estimates of the collectability of our accounts receivable by analyzing historical bad debts, specific customer creditworthiness, and current economic trends.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P10_S2	If the financial condition of our customers were to deteriorate such that their ability to make payments to us was impaired, additional allowances could be required.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	Inventory Inventory consists primarily of solar energy system components (such as solar panels and inverters) located in various warehouse facilities and finished goods held for sale at our Solar Living Center located in Hopland, California.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	We state our inventory at the lower of cost (first-in, first-out method) or market.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P11_S2	We identify the inventory items to be written down for obsolescence based on the item s current sales status and condition.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P11_S3	We write down discontinued or slow moving inventories based on an estimate of the markdown to retail price needed to sell through our current stock level of the inventories.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	Goodwill Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase consideration over the estimated fair value of assets acquired less liabilities assumed in a business acquisition.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently if impairment indicators arise.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	We compare the estimated fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	If the estimated fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill of the reporting unit is considered not impaired.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	If the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value, the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P13_S3	Since we operate in only one business segment, we assess impairment at the enterprise level.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	The annual process of evaluating the potential impairment of goodwill is highly subjective and requires significant judgment at many points during the analysis.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	In assessing our goodwill for impairment, we use a combination of factors, including comparable company market values and multiples of revenue to the extent the information is available.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P14_S2	If comparable market information is insufficient, we expect to supplement our assessment with other approaches, such as present value techniques, which will require us to make estimates and judgments about our future cash flows.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P14_S3	These cash flow forecasts will be based on assumptions that are consistent with the plans and estimates we use to manage our business.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P14_S4	Application of alternative assumptions could yield significantly different results.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	We account for the acquisition of a controlling interest in a business using the purchase method.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	In determining the estimated fair value of certain acquired assets and liabilities, we make assumptions based upon historical and other relevant information and, in some cases, independent expert appraisals.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P15_S2	Assumptions may be incomplete, and unanticipated events and circumstances may occur that could affect the validity of such assumptions, estimates, or actual results.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	Stock-Based Compensation We recognize compensation cost for share-based awards based on the estimated fair value of the award on date of grant.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P16_S1	We measure compensation cost at the grant date based on the estimated fair value of the award and recognize compensation cost upon the probable attainment of a specified performance condition or over a service period.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P16_S2	We use the Black-Scholes option pricing model to estimate the fair value for purposes of accounting and disclosures.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P16_S3	In calculating this fair value, there are certain highly subjective assumptions that we use, consisting of estimated market value of our stock, the expected life of the option, risk-free interest rate, dividend yield, and volatility.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P16_S4	The use of a different estimate for any one of these components could have a material impact on the amount of calculated compensation expense.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	Income Taxes We provide for income taxes pursuant to the liability method.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P17_S1	The liability method requires recognition of deferred income taxes based on temporary differences between financial reporting and income tax bases of assets and liabilities, using current enacted income tax rates and regulations.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P17_S2	These differences will result in taxable income or deductions in future years when the reported amount of the asset or liability is recovered or settled, respectively.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P17_S3	Considerable judgment is required in determining when these events may occur and whether recovery of an asset, including the utilization of a net operating loss carryforward prior to its expiration, is more likely than not.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P17_S4	We must recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P17_S5	We measure the tax benefits recognized in the consolidated financial statements from such a position based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate resolution.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	The application of income tax law is inherently complex.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	Laws and regulations in this area are voluminous and are often ambiguous.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	As such, we are required to make many subjective assumptions and judgments regarding our income tax exposures.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P18_S3	Interpretations of and guidance surrounding income tax law and regulations change over time and may result in changes to our subjective assumptions and judgments which can materially affect amounts recognized in our consolidated financial statements.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	Results of Operations Year Ended December 31, 2011 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2010 Net revenue .
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S1	Net revenue increased $31.9 million, or 41.3%, to $109.3 million during 2011 from $77.3 million during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S2	All of the revenue growth was attributable to our acquisition of Alteris.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S3	Gross profit increased $6.4 million, or 29.5%, to $27.9 million during 2011 from $21.5 million during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S4	As a percentage of net revenue, gross profit decreased to 25.5% during 2011 from 27.8% during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S5	The decrease in gross profit percentage was due to an increase in the mix of commercial revenue, as well as lower average margins on those commercial projects.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P19_S6	Gross margins for residential improved in the latter half of 2011 as compared to the prior year due to improved selling practices and lower module pricing.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	Selling and operating expenses increased $6.9 million, or 41.4%, to $23.6 million during 2011 from $16.7 million during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S1	As a percentage of net revenue, selling and operating expenses remained constant at 21.6% during 2011 and 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S2	Approximately three-quarters of the increase in selling and operating expenses was due to the consolidation of Alteris, with the remainder due to increases in marketing spend, sales commissions, and travel expenses.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S3	General and administrative expenses increased $1.3 million, or 48.2%, to $4.1 million during 2011 from $2.8 million during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S4	As a percentage of net revenue, general and administrative expenses increased to 3.8% during 2011 from 3.6% during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S5	Approximately three-quarters of the increase in general and administrative expenses was due to the consolidation of Alteris, with the remainder due to the addition of senior management positions.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S6	Acquisition-related costs were $2.4 million during 2011 and were the result of our acquisition of Alteris.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S7	Income tax benefit during 2011 was reduced by certain nondeductible acquisition-related costs for the Alteris acquisition that for tax purposes were capitalized into the basis of the stock investment.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S8	As a result of the above factors, net loss was $1.9 million during 2011 compared to net income of $1.2 million during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S9	Net loss per share was $0.08 during 2011 compared to net income per share of $0.07 during 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S10	Year Ended December 31, 2010 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2009 Net revenue.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S11	Net revenue increased $13.0 million, or 20.2%, to $77.3 million during 2010 from $64.3 million during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S12	All the revenue growth was organic and was primarily driven by an increase in marketing and sales initiatives.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S13	Gross profit increased $5.6 million, or 34.8%, to $21.5 million during 2010 from $16.0 million during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S14	As a percentage of net revenue, gross profit increased to 27.8% during 2010 from 24.8% during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S15	The increase in gross profit percentage is approximately two-thirds due to declines in solar module prices over the last year and from improved selling and installation practices.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S16	No further significant changes to the gross profit margin are anticipated.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S17	Selling and operating expenses increased $0.5 million, or 3.1%, to $16.7 million during 2010 from $16.2 million during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S18	As a percentage of net revenue, selling and operating expenses decreased to 21.6% during 2010 from 25.2% during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S19	The decrease in selling and operating expenses primarily reflects the significant cost savings achieved by integrating previously acquired businesses onto a single set of systems and a unified brand.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S20	Further leveraging of the selling and operating expenses, as a percentage of net revenue, is expected as sales continue to grow.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S21	General and administrative expenses increased $0.4 million, or 18.5%, to $2.8 million during 2010 from $2.3 million during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S22	As a percentage of net revenue, general and administrative expenses remained consistent at 3.6% during each of the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S23	As a result of the above factors, net income was $1.2 million during 2010 compared to a net loss of $1.6 million during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S24	Net income per share was $0.07 per share during 2010 compared to a net loss of $0.09 per share during 2009.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S25	The following table sets forth our unaudited quarterly results of operations during each of the quarters in 2011 and 2010.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S26	We believe this unaudited financial information includes all adjustments, consisting solely of normal recurring accruals and adjustments, necessary for a fair presentation of the results of operations for the quarters presented.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P20_S27	This financial information should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and related notes included elsewhere in this Form 10-K.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	The results of operations for any quarter are not necessarily indicative of future results of operations.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	Our quarterly net revenue and operating results for solar energy system installations are difficult to predict and have in the past and may in the future fluctuate from quarter to quarter as a result of changes in state, federal, or private utility company subsidies, as well as weather, economic trends and other factors.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	We have historically experienced seasonality in our solar installation business, with the first quarter representing our slowest installation quarter of the year.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P23_S1	Much of the seasonality in our business in past years has been offset by the timing of government activities as well as strong organic growth.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P23_S2	With the addition of Alteris, we expect increased seasonal fluctuations due to the severity of winters in the northeast.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources Our capital needs arise from capital related to acquisitions of new businesses, working capital required to fund our purchases of solar PV modules and inverters, replacements, expansions and improvements to our infrastructure, and future growth.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P24_S1	These capital requirements depend on numerous factors, including business acquisitions, the ability to attract new solar energy system installation customers, market acceptance of our product offerings, the cost of ongoing upgrades to our product offerings, the level of expenditures for sales and marketing, the level of investment in support systems and facilities and other factors.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P24_S2	The timing and amount of these capital requirements are variable and may fluctuate from time to time and cannot accurately be predicted.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P24_S3	Recently we acquired Alteris, a large solar integrator, and we anticipate significant capital requirements as a result of the acquisition.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P24_S4	To the extent we have or can arrange available capital, we plan to continue to pursue acquisitions and other opportunities to expand our sales territories, technologies, and products and increase our sales and marketing programs as needed.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P24_S5	We did not have any material commitments for capital expenditures as of December 31, 2011, and we do not presently have any plans for future material capital expenditures.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	On July 22, 2011, Alteris entered into a new financing arrangement with a bank to fund commercial solar installations.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P25_S1	Under a master lease agreement between a project finance subsidiary of Alteris and the bank, the project finance subsidiary may form new subsidiaries that will enter into sale leaseback arrangements with solar installation customers to finance specifically designated solar installations.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P25_S2	The project finance entities will grant a security interest in substantially all their assets, and the project finance subsidiary s equity will be pledged by Alteris on a non-recourse basis to the bank.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P25_S3	Alteris will provide limited unsecured guarantees of payment and performance of the obligations of the project finance entities, including operating, maintenance and indemnity obligations and payment of certain fees and expenses.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P25_S4	This financing arrangement would not generate capital for use in our business, but instead would offer a financing alternative to our commercial installation customers.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P25_S5	As of December 31, 2011, there were no commercial solar installations funded under this financing arrangement.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	On December 19, 2011, we entered into a Loan and Security Agreement with a bank (the Loan and Security Agreement ).
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S1	The Loan and Security Agreement replaces previous credit arrangements between the bank and Alteris.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S2	The Loan and Security Agreement provides for a revolving line of credit with advances of up to $7 million based upon the collateral value of our accounts receivable.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S3	All borrowings are collateralized by a security interest in substantially all of our assets other than our interests in Alteris Project Financing Company LLC, and bear interest at (i) the greater of the bank s prime rate or 4.00%, plus (ii) 1.75% (or 5.75% during an event of default) unless we maintain certain liquidity benchmarks.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S4	The line of credit facility will mature on August 31, 2012.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S5	The line of credit has a facility fee of 0.5% per year of the average daily unused portion of the available line of credit during the applicable calendar quarter.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P26_S6	The borrowers may reserve up to $500,000 for stand-by letters of credit under the line of credit.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	Agreement contains various covenants, including a covenant requiring compliance with a liquidity ratio defined in the Loan and Security Agreement.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	The obligations may be accelerated upon an event of default, including covenant and payment defaults, material adverse change, defaults under other indebtedness giving rise to the right to accelerate payment of such indebtedness, final judgments of at least $50,000, and the borrowers insolvency or bankruptcy, among other things.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	Pursuant to the Loan and Security Agreement, we have guaranteed the obligations of the borrowers under the Loan and Security Agreement and collateralized our guaranty obligations by a security interest in substantially all of our assets under a separate Security Agreement, dated December 19, 2011, with the lender.
1425565_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	Upon the closing of the Alteris transaction on December 19, 2011, we received a commitment from Riverside Renewable Energy Investments, LLC ( Riverside ), the former majority owner of Earth Friendly Energy Holding Group, LLC d/b/a Alteris Renewables, Inc., to make a single cash advance to us up to $3.15 million and from Gaiam to advance us up to $1.7 million.

1425565_12_ITEM8_P9_S0	Cash Cash represents demand deposit accounts with financial institutions that are denominated in U.S. dollars.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P9_S1	Concentration of Risk and Allowance for Doubtful Accounts We have a potential concentration of credit risk in our accounts receivable in that a financing company that purchases and then leases installed solar energy system to host users and two commercial customers accounted for 20.2%, 12.8%, and 11.8%, respectively, of our accounts receivable as of December 31, 2011.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P9_S2	We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P9_S3	We make estimates of the collectability of our accounts receivable by analyzing historical bad debts, specific customer creditworthiness and current economic trends.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P9_S4	The allowance for doubtful accounts was $0.5 million and $0.3 million at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P9_S5	If the financial condition of our customers or the public utilities or financing companies were to deteriorate such that their ability to make payments to us was impaired, additional allowances could be required.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P10_S0	Sales to our largest three customers for 2011 accounted for approximately 20%, 13% and 11%, respectively, of our total net revenue.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P10_S1	Inventory Inventory consists primarily of solar energy system components (such as solar panels and inverters) located at our various warehouses and finished goods held for sale at our Solar Living Center located in Hopland, California.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P10_S2	We state our inventory at the lower of cost (first-in, first-out method) or market.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P10_S3	We identify the inventory items to be written down for obsolescence based on the item s current sales status and condition.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P10_S4	We write down discontinued or slow moving inventories based on an estimate of the markdown to retail price needed to sell through our current stock level of the inventories.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P10_S5	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, we estimated obsolete or slow-moving inventory to be $0.2 million.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S0	Prior to 2011, Gaiam, Inc. ( Gaiam ) had historically fulfilled approximately 80% of our catalog and Internet sales through its central distribution center.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S1	We paid Gaiam supplier product costs, order fulfillment fees, and freight charges to drop-ship these sales to our customers, which payments are made through our Intercorporate Services Agreement.

1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S3	We were responsible for the selling, marketing, and providing of these products to our customers and have our own customer service department to ensure the acceptability of our products.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S4	We beared the credit risk for the amount being billed to our customer.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S5	We leveraged our multichannel distribution (web promotions and our retail outlet located at the Solar Living Center) to market slow-moving or obsolete products.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S6	Deferred Advertising Costs Prior to 2011, we had deferred advertising costs related to the preparation, printing, advertising and distribution of catalogs.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S7	We deferred such costs for financial reporting purposes until the catalogs were distributed, then amortized such costs over succeeding periods on the basis of estimated direct relationship sales.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S8	We amortized seasonal catalogs within seven months and our annual catalogs within one year.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P11_S9	Forecasted sales statistics were the principal factor used in estimating the amortization rate.

1425565_12_ITEM8_P13_S0	Property and Equipment We state property and equipment at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P13_S1	We compute depreciation of property and equipment on the straight-line method over estimated useful lives, generally three to twenty years.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P13_S2	We amortize leasehold and building improvements over the shorter of the estimated useful lives of the assets or the remaining term of the lease or remaining life of the building, respectively.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P14_S0	Goodwill and Other Intangibles Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase consideration over the estimated fair value of assets acquired less liabilities assumed in a business acquisition.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P14_S1	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently if impairment indicators arise.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P15_S0	We compare the estimated fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P15_S1	If the estimated fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill of the reporting unit is considered not impaired.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P15_S2	If the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its estimated fair value, the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P15_S3	Since we operate in only one business segment, we assess impairment at the enterprise level.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P16_S0	The annual process of evaluating the potential impairment of goodwill is highly subjective and requires significant judgment at many points during the analysis.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P16_S1	In assessing our goodwill for impairment, we use a combination of factors, including comparable company market values and multiples of revenue to the extent the information is available.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P16_S2	If comparable market information is insufficient, we expect to supplement our assessment with other approaches, such as present value techniques, which will require us to make estimates and judgments about our future cash flows.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P16_S3	These cash flow forecasts will be based on assumptions that are consistent with the plans and estimates we use to manage our business.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P16_S4	Application of alternative assumptions could yield significantly different results.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P17_S0	Our goodwill balances were $19.9 million and $0.7 million at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, and our other intangibles balances were $0.4 million and nil at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P17_S1	The goodwill increase was attributable to our acquisition of Alteris during 2011.

1425565_12_ITEM8_P19_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue consists primarily of solar energy system installation.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P19_S1	We recognize revenue from fixed price contracts using either the completed or percentage-of-completion method, based on the size of the energy system installation.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P20_S0	As a result of a recent business acquisition (see Note 3.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P20_S1	Mergers and Acquisitions), we slightly modified our method of applying revenue recognition for fixed price contracts in that we now recognize revenue from energy system installations of less than 100 kilowatts, or kW, when the installation is substantially complete, while we recognize revenue from energy system installations equal to or greater than 100 kW on a percentage-of-completion basis, measured by the percentage of contract costs incurred to date to total estimated costs for each contract.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P20_S2	We recognize amounts billed to customers for postage and handling as revenue at the same time that the revenues arising from the product sale are recognized.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P20_S3	We include postage and handling costs, which were approximately $0.1 million for 2011 and $0.2 million each year for 2010 and 2009, in selling and operating expense along with other fulfillment costs.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P21_S0	The assets Costs in excess of billings on uncompleted contracts and Deferred costs on uncompleted contracts represent costs incurred plus estimated earnings in excess of amounts billed on percentage-of-completion method contracts and costs incurred but not recognizable until recognition of the related contract revenue on completed-method contracts, respectively.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P21_S1	The liability Billings in excess of costs on uncompleted contracts represents billings in excess of related costs on percentage-of-completion method contracts.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P22_S0	We bill our large installation customers for contract performance progress according to milestones defined in their respective contracts.

1425565_12_ITEM8_P24_S0	Share-Based Compensation We recognize compensation cost for stock-based awards based on the estimated fair value of the award on date of grant.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P24_S1	We measure compensation cost at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and recognize compensation cost upon the probable attainment of a specified performance condition or over a service period.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P24_S2	We use the Black-Scholes option valuation model to estimate the fair value for purposes of accounting and disclosures.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P24_S3	In estimating this fair value, there are certain assumptions that we use, as disclosed in Note 10.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P25_S0	Share-Based Compensation, consisting of the expected life of the option, risk-free interest rate, dividend yield, volatility and forfeiture rate.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P25_S1	The use of a different estimate for any one of these components could have a material impact on the amount of calculated compensation expense.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P26_S0	Income Taxes We provide for income taxes pursuant to the liability method.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P26_S1	The liability method requires recognition of deferred income taxes based on temporary differences between financial reporting and income tax bases of assets and liabilities, using current enacted income tax rates and regulations.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P26_S2	These differences will result in taxable income or deductions in future years when the reported amount of the asset or liability is recovered or settled, respectively.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P26_S3	Considerable judgment is required in determining when these events may occur and whether recovery of an asset is more likely than not.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P27_S0	Our effective tax rate remains fairly consistent.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P27_S1	We have significant NOL carryforwards and more likely than not expect our deferred tax assets to be fully recoverable through the reversal of taxable temporary differences in future years as a result of normal business activities.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P27_S2	We have agreed under our tax sharing agreement with Gaiam to make payments to Gaiam as we utilize certain of our NOLs in the future.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P27_S3	We must recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P27_S4	We measure the tax benefits recognized in the consolidated financial statements from such a position based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate resolution.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S0	The application of income tax law is inherently complex.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S1	Laws and regulations in this area are voluminous and are often ambiguous.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S2	As such, we are required to make many subjective assumptions and judgments regarding our income tax exposures.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S3	Interpretations of and guidance surrounding income tax law and regulations change over time and may result in changes to our subjective assumptions and judgments which can materially affect amounts recognized in our consolidated balance sheets and statements of operations.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S4	The result of the reassessment of our tax positions did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S5	Our federal and state tax returns for all years after 2008 are subject to future examination by tax authorities for all our tax jurisdictions.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P28_S6	We recognize interest and penalties related to income tax matters in interest expense and general and administration expenses, respectively.

( Alteris ) on June 21, 2011 (the acquisition date ).

1425565_12_ITEM8_P60_S0	both plans are generally granted with an exercise price equal to the closing market price of our stock on the date of the grant.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P61_S0	Options vest based on performance (attainment of a certain amount of pre-tax income for a given year), service conditions, or some combination thereof.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P61_S1	Grants typically expire seven years from the date of grant.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P62_S0	The determination of the estimated fair value of share-based payment awards on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model is affected by our stock price as well as assumptions regarding a number of complex and subjective variables.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P63_S0	Expected volatilities are based on a value calculated using the combination of historical volatility of comparable public companies in our industry and our stock price volatility since our initial public offering.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P63_S1	Expected life is based on the specific vesting terms of the option and anticipated changes to market value and expected employee exercise behavior.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P64_S0	The risk-free interest rate used in the option valuation model is based on U.S. Treasury zero-coupon issues with remaining terms similar to the expected term on the options.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P64_S1	We do not anticipate paying any cash dividends on our Class A common stock in the foreseeable future and, therefore, an expected dividend yield of zero is used in the option valuation model.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P65_S0	We are required to estimate forfeitures at the time of grant and revise those estimates in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P65_S1	We primarily use historical data by participant groupings to estimate option forfeitures and record share-based compensation expense only for those awards that are expected to vest.

1425565_12_ITEM8_P75_S0	The Internal Revenue Code contains provisions that limit the net operating loss available for use in any given year upon the occurrence of certain events, including significant changes in ownership interest.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P75_S1	A change in ownership of a company of greater than 50% within a three-year period results in an annual limitation on the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards from tax periods prior to the ownership changes.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P75_S2	Certain of our net operating loss carryforwards as of December 31, 2011 are subject to annual limitations due to changes in ownership.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P75_S3	Additionally, to the extent we become entitled to utilize certain loss carryforwards relating to periods prior to our initial public offering, we are required under the terms of our tax sharing agreement with Gaiam to distribute to Gaiam the tax effect (estimated to be 34% for federal income tax purposes) of the amount of such tax loss carryforwards so utilized.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P76_S0	These net operating loss carryforwards expire beginning in 2018 if not utilized.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P77_S0	Due to Gaiam s step acquisitions of our company, we experienced ownership changes as defined in Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P77_S1	Accordingly, our use of the net operating loss carryforwards is limited by annual limitations described in Sections 382 and 383 of the Internal Revenue Code.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P77_S2	As of December 31, 2011, $4.4 million of these net operating loss carryforwards remained available for current and future utilization, meaning that potential future payments to Gaiam, which would be made over a period of several years, could therefore aggregate to approximately $1.6 million based on current tax rates.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P77_S3	We expect the remainder of our deferred tax assets at December 31, 2011 to be fully recoverable through the reversal of taxable temporary differences and normal business activities in future years.
1425565_12_ITEM8_P77_S4	Accordingly, no other valuation allowances for deferred tax items were considered necessary as of December 31, 2011.

1425565_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Disclosure Controls and Procedures Our chief executive officer and chief financial officer conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and Rule 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon their evaluation as of December 31, 2011, they have concluded that those disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2011 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P1_S1	We are responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) and Rule 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P1_S4	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P2_S0	We assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P2_S1	In making the assessment, we used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control-Integrated Framework .
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on that assessment, we concluded that, as of December 31, 2011, our internal control over financial reporting is effective based on those criteria.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P2_S3	This annual report does not include an attestation report of our registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1425565_12_ITEM9A_P2_S4	Management s report was not subject to attestation by our registered public accounting firm pursuant to rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit us to provide only management s report in this annual report.

(the Company ) on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2011, as filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the Report ), I, Erik Zech, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1425565_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	We are a leading residential and commercial solar energy engineering, procurement, and construction firm.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	We also perform most of our own sales and marketing activities to generate leads and secure projects.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	We offer turnkey services, including design, procurement, permitting, build-out, grid connection, financing referrals and warranty and customer satisfaction activities.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our solar energy systems use high-quality solar photovoltaic modules from manufacturers such as Canadian Solar and SunPower.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S1	We use proven technologies and techniques to help customers achieve meaningful savings by reducing their utility costs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S2	In addition, we help customers lower their emissions output and reliance upon fossil fuel energy sources.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S3	We have over 30 years of experience in residential solar energy.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S4	We trace our roots to 1978, when Real Goods Trading Corporation sold the first solar photovoltaic, or PV, panels in the United States.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S5	We have designed and installed over 14,000 residential and commercial solar systems since our founding.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S6	Our focused customer acquisition approach and our efficiency in converting customer leads into sales enable us to have what we believe are competitive customer acquisition costs that we continuously focus on improving.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P1_S7	We believe that our Real Goods Solar brand has a national reputation for high quality customer service in the solar energy market, which leads to a significant number of word-of-mouth referrals and new customers.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our History We were incorporated in Colorado in 2008 as a successor to Gaiam Energy Tech, Inc. founded in 1999.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	Our second acquisition was Real Goods Trading Corporation, which was publicly traded from 1991 to 2001 when it was acquired by Gaiam Energy Tech, Inc., a subsidiary of Gaiam, Inc. ( Gaiam ).
1425565_13_ITEM1_P2_S2	We operated essentially as a separate business (except for certain consolidated corporate functions) from 2001 to 2008, when operations were moved into our corporate entity, Real Goods Solar, Inc., upon its formation.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P2_S3	We acquired Marin Solar in November 2007, Carlson Solar in January 2008, Independent Energy Systems ( IES ) in August 2008, Regrid Power, Inc. ( Regrid Power ) in October 2008, and Earth Friendly Energy Group Holdings LLC d/b/a Alteris Renewables, Inc. ( Alteris ) in June 2011.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P2_S4	Our goal is to continue to build on our industry-leading position and become one of the largest and most profitable residential and commercial solar energy integrators in the United States.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P2_S5	We intend to pursue the following strategies to achieve this goal:
1425565_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	Enhance and leverage the Real Goods Solar brand name to increase our market presence .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P3_S1	We intend to enhance and leverage the Real Goods Solar brand name and our reputation for customer service to continue to win business in existing markets and to expand into new markets in which our competitors have little or no brand recognition.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	Expand into markets in which legislation and government incentives are favorable for solar energy .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	We plan to expand the geographic scope of our business as jurisdictions adopt new or improve existing incentive programs that enhance the economics of solar energy systems for a broader customer base.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	In addition to the $3.4 billion California Solar Initiative, or CSI, adopted in 2007, a number of states, including Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Hawaii, Massachusetts, Nevada, New Jersey and New York, have adopted legislation and incentives favorable to solar energy and other states are considering adopting such legislation and incentives.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	Federal law provides a 30% investment tax credit that was extended for eight years in 2008, when the $2,000 cap on the credit for residential systems was removed.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	We believe that this tax credit will continue to stimulate the solar market on a national basis.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	Consolidate the fragmented U.S. solar energy system installation market .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	The U.S. solar energy system installation market remains highly fragmented, with hundreds of independent installers or integrators in California alone.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	We have completed a number of acquisitions as part of a consolidation strategy and although we now focus primarily on organic growth, we will continue to look at appropriate acquisition opportunities to strengthen the company and increase our market reach.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P8_S2	We plan to create economies of scale in order to increase our operating efficiencies, with a goal of improving our margins and profitability.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	Expand our community of customers to enhance revenue and lower our customer acquisition costs .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	We intend to leverage the reputation for authenticity associated with our Real Goods Solar brand to expand our community of customers, which cares deeply about solar energy and a renewable energy lifestyle and views us as the premier solar energy engineering, procurement, and construction firm.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P9_S2	We intend to leverage our customer base to continue to provide us with new leads and referrals, which, in conjunction with our marketing efforts, should allow us to continue to lower our customer acquisition costs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	Make a difference in the world .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	We intend to promote our solar energy systems as a way for individuals and communities to reduce their carbon footprint, eliminate U.S. dependence on foreign and fossil fuel-based energy sources and foster a culture of respect for the Earth and its natural resources for the benefit of future generations.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	Competitive Advantages We believe that we have a number of advantages over our competitors, including the following:
1425565_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	We believe that our customers often buy our solar energy systems because of the strength of the Real Goods Solar brand, our longevity in the marketplace and our reputation for excellent customer service.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	As a result of over 30 years of operating in the solar energy industry, we believe that we are frequently the first company in the industry approached by new solar companies with innovative products.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	We have a highly experienced management team.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	Our Chief Executive Officer, Kamyar (Kam) Mofid, has a wealth of experience and expertise managing national and international organizations and has a deep knowledge of the solar sector.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P13_S2	In addition, Jirka Rysavy, non-executive Chairman of our Board of Directors, founded and grew Corporate Express from $30 million to $3 billion in revenue in less than five years, and founded Gaiam.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P13_S3	Members of our management team, as well as Mr. Rysavy, have considerable experience in the consolidation of fragmented industries, having acquired over 250 companies.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our business model gives us a significant marketing advantage by providing us access to potential purchasers of solar energy systems from visitors to our Solar Living Center and from our strong web presence.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P14_S1	In addition, our strong brand name and reputation for outstanding customer service provide us with word-of-mouth referrals.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P14_S2	We closely monitor our customer acquisitions costs and have strategies in place to continue to reduce these costs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P14_S3	We believe that as demand for electric power increases, the electric power industry will face various challenges, including the following:
1425565_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	Power industry at peak capacity with aging infrastructure .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	A majority of U.S. power plants in highly populated areas approach capacity during times of peak usage.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P15_S2	Additionally, over half of U.S. power plants are more than 30 years old.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P15_S3	In order to meet the rising demand for electric power, additional plants will need to be constructed and the aging existing plant infrastructure will require significant capital investment.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	Although coal, the largest non-renewable energy resource, is estimated to have over 100 years of reserves left, the rate of global energy consumption is expected to continue to increase, jeopardizing economical access to sufficient energy supply for future generations if renewable energy sources are not developed.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	As a result of aging infrastructure and high energy demand, residential and commercial customers are facing rising electricity rates, creating economic pressures for consumers and businesses alike.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	Pollution and climate change concerns .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	Non-renewable, fossil fuel-based energy sources, including coal, create environmental pollution, and there is significant local resistance to new coal-fired power plants in populated areas.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P18_S2	Concerns about climate change, global warming and greenhouse gas emissions have resulted in international efforts to reduce such emissions, and various states have enacted stricter emissions control laws or mandated that utilities comply with renewable portfolio standards ( RPS ), which require the generation of a certain amount of power from renewable sources.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P18_S3	We believe that increased concerns about climate change are likely to result in increased focus on alternative energy sources.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P18_S4	Because the solar energy industry offers solutions to these challenges, we believe it has extremely large growth potential.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	Currently, less than one percent of the world s power is generated from solar energy sources.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P19_S1	Drivers of Solar Energy Industry Growth We expect a number of factors will contribute to growth in the solar energy industry, including the following:
1425565_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	A number of initiatives have been enacted by the federal government and various states, municipalities and utilities that encourage or require the installation of grid-tied solar energy systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P20_S1	In 1996, the state of California enabled individual energy systems to tie into the conventional utility grid and began to require that various rebates and incentives be provided to support the use of solar energy systems, making California the focus for the development of the solar energy market in the United States.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P20_S2	California has mandated an increase in the percentage of renewable energy retail sales by certain utilities to 20%, with a goal of 33% by 2020.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P20_S3	Colorado has enacted an RPS goal of 20% for investor-owned utilities and 10% for electric cooperatives and municipal utilities serving more than 40,000 customers by 2020.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	The various states in the northeast in which we operate have also implemented a variety of solar initiatives.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	As RPS programs are implemented, it is common for financial incentives to be made available, making the purchase of solar energy systems more affordable and opening additional solar markets in the United States.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	Rebates offered to customers or integrators reduce the initial cost of solar energy systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P23_S1	Several states, including California and Colorado, require certain utilities to offer rebates that can substantially reduce the costs of installing solar energy systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P23_S2	These rebates, coupled with tax credits, substantially reduce the customer s out-of-pocket cost for purchasing a solar energy system.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	There is currently a 30% federal tax credit for residential and commercial solar energy systems, and in October 2008 Congress extended the availability of this credit for both residential and commercial solar installations for another eight years and eliminated the $2,000 cap on the tax credit for residential installations.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	Other incentives, such as net metering, time-of-use credits and performance-based incentives, are provided to consumers based on the amount of electricity their solar energy systems generate.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P25_S1	Currently, over three quarters of the states have required some of their utility providers to accept net metering.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	Net metering allows residential and small-scale commercial solar energy producers to sell excess power generated by their systems to their utility companies, through existing electric meters, at standard retail prices.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	Time-of-use metering allows customers to sell solar power to their utility for higher rates during peak times when traditional loads are at their highest demand.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P26_S2	These customers can then buy back electricity from the utilities during off-peak times at a much lower rate, providing them an additional financial benefit for solar installations.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	Performance-based incentives, or PBIs, reward customers based on the generation of their solar energy over time, as opposed to through an initial rebate.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	In many states, the installation of a solar energy system generates a renewable energy credit, which is marketable in certain states.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	In certain jurisdictions, such as California, assessors are prohibited from increasing a solar energy system owner s property tax assessment as a result of the added value of qualified solar energy systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	Benefits of solar energy systems .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P30_S1	Solar energy as a source of electrical power offers the following benefits compared to conventional energy sources:
1425565_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	The cost of electricity generated by a solar energy system is essentially fixed at the time of installation, providing a hedge against utility electricity price increases and inflation.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	Solar energy systems generate much of their electricity during the afternoon when the sun s rays are strongest and when the greatest demand for electricity for air conditioning occurs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P32_S1	Customers can use their solar energy systems energy to replace peak time conventional electricity, which can be more expensive and less reliable than electricity purchased during non-peak times.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P32_S2	In addition, solar energy systems typically have low operating expenses because the systems require minimal maintenance over their expected lives.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P33_S0	Versatility and ease of installation .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P34_S0	Solar energy systems can generate electricity in any location that receives sunlight, while relatively fewer locations have both the infrastructure and natural resources required to support other forms of renewable energy, including hydroelectric, wind and geothermal.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P34_S1	Solar energy systems can be installed directly at sites where power is needed, reducing conventional electrical transmission and distribution costs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P35_S0	The use of solar energy systems improves energy security by reducing fossil fuel purchases from hostile or politically or economically unstable countries and by reducing power strains on local electrical transmission and distribution systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P35_S1	Challenges to the Solar Energy Industry We believe growth in the solar energy industry faces the following challenges:
1425565_13_ITEM1_P36_S0	The decision to install a solar energy system represents a significant investment of approximately $10,000 to $30,000 or more (net of rebates and federal tax credits), if purchased outright, for the typical home.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P36_S1	Financing sources specifically for solar energy systems, including loans and system leases, are not always available depending upon the state and the customer s credit rating.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P36_S2	The return on each customer s investment in a solar energy system will occur over a different period or at a different rate depending upon individual circumstances.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P36_S3	A potential purchaser has to weigh the costs associated with the initial investment decision against the potential benefit associated with anticipated longer-term utility cost reductions, increased property value and low system maintenance costs provided by a solar energy system.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P37_S0	The solar energy industry is significantly driven by federal, state and local regulations and incentives, which are continually changing.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P37_S1	Changes in regulations and incentives could adversely affect the economic viability of solar energy systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P38_S0	Supply of solar PV modules .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P38_S1	At times in recent years, there has been a global shortage of solar PV modules, which has resulted in some price increases and limited availability for solar PV modules.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P38_S2	While we believe that the risk of future shortages has abated, it is always a possibility.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P38_S3	In addition, other problems with the supply chain could impair the timely delivery of key system components.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P39_S0	Cost of traditional energy sources .
1425565_13_ITEM1_P40_S0	The cost of solar power generation is often compared by customers to the cost of traditional sources of electricity generation such as coal.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P40_S1	Traditional power plants are relatively cheap to build but expensive to operate when the true price of their environmental impact is considered.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P40_S2	Solar power plants are more expensive to build but cheaper to operate over the long-term, with minimal environmental impact.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P40_S3	The growth of the solar power industry is dependent on how consumers weigh the relative importance of construction costs relative to the operating costs for both types of electricity production and the extent to which government mandates require traditional power plants to incorporate environmental costs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P41_S0	The challenging economic environment has created a challenging business climate for the purchase of solar systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P41_S1	We believe that many customers remain interested in solar but are electing to postpone their decision to install a system until they have better visibility into the economy and their own personal financial situation.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S0	The solar industry has been growing very rapidly and the competitive landscape has evolved.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S1	Our historically strong position, in particular in the residential sector, has been challenged by existing and new competitors.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S2	We must continue to improve and evolve to be able to grow profitability.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S3	We offer turnkey solar energy services, including design, procurement, permitting, build-out, grid connection, financing referrals and warranty and customer satisfaction activities.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S4	We install residential and commercial systems that are generally between 3 kilowatts, or kW, and 1megawatt, or MW, output, with the average residential installation being approximately 6 kW output.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S5	We also on occasion install larger commercial projects in the 3-5 MW range.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S6	We design and build our solar energy systems to meet each customer s individual needs and circumstances.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S7	We assess a customer s annual power requirements and average daily consumption rates in different seasons of the year to size the solar energy system and engineer its wiring.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S8	We assess the customer s roof size, configuration, and composition to determine the optimum location for the solar PV modules.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S9	We factor in information about the customer s electrical service territory and its rate structures and the customer s budget and preferred financing method, as well as the customer s aesthetic preferences.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S10	We also identify the relevant federal, state and local regulations, including building codes, which are important to the cost, operation and return on investment of the customer s solar energy system, as well as relevant tax rates and various other factors.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S11	We assess this data using solar monitoring tools and analytical calculations, which enable us to design a solar energy system to a size and configuration that maximizes energy efficiency for each customer s circumstances.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S12	We prepare final construction plans to obtain a building permit which is necessary for rebate processing.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P42_S13	We also provide customers with a return on investment analysis and determine the rebates and performance-based incentives that are available to each customer.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P43_S0	As soon as the building permit is approved, our installation professionals begin the installation by placing metal racking on the customer s roof (or by building a ground mount in certain situations), followed by installation of the solar PV modules, inverter(s) and the balance of systems components and safety equipment.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P43_S1	We do not custom manufacture solar PV modules or inverters, but rather purchase these manufactured components for incorporation into our constructed solar energy systems.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P43_S2	After the solar PV modules and inverter(s) are installed on the customer s home or business, we obtain a final inspection of the installation by the local building department, prepare and submit all rebate applications to the appropriate rebating jurisdiction and at the same time apply for the local utility company to interconnect the customer s solar energy system to the utility grid.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P43_S3	The entire process from signing of the contract through final inspection by the local building department typically takes between 60 to 90 days, with the actual installation work usually requiring two to three days.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P44_S0	A basic solar energy system has no moving parts and consists of a number of solar PV modules wired together and mounted on a metal framing structure, an inverter and the balance of systems and safety equipment necessary to connect the system to the customer s existing utility service.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P45_S0	We source solar PV modules from several primary manufacturers: Canadian Solar and SunPower.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P45_S1	These modules range in conversion efficiency from 14% to 16%.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P46_S0	Solar PV modules can be manufactured using different semiconductor materials, including mono- and poly-crystalline silicon, amorphous silicon, gallium arsenide, copper indium gallium selenide, or CIGS, and cadmium telluride.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P47_S0	Developments in solar PV technology have generated advances in the conversion efficiency of solar PV cells, reductions in manufacturing costs and improvements in manufacturing yields.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P48_S0	An inverter is an electronic device that converts the low-voltage DC power generated by solar PV modules to conventional 120-volt AC power used by standard household lights and appliances.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P48_S1	While an inverter may need to be replaced approximately 15 years after installation, other system components typically do not require replacement during the 20- to 25-year warranty period applicable to solar PV modules.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P49_S0	Individual solar energy systems are connected to the utility grid by an inverter, which also allows the excess electricity produced to flow into the grid, causing the customer s electric meter effectively to run backwards, to the credit of the customer s utility account, sometimes at standard retail prices.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P49_S1	A customer that has a grid-connected solar energy system draws energy from the grid through the conventional local utility when the sun is not shining, or when household energy consumption exceeds the solar energy system s energy generation capacity.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S0	Warranty Terms Most manufacturers of solar PV modules currently offer a 20- to 25-year transferable warranty of their products.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S1	We offer a 10-year parts and labor warranty, which may also involve claims of property damage arising from the installation.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S2	We generally handle manufacturer warranty claims for solar PV modules as part of our customer service and we are typically reimbursed by the manufacturers for our labor and materials.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S3	Historically, our costs associated with warranty claims have been minimal.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S4	Financing While many of our customers choose to purchase their solar energy systems without the use of financing, we also connect our customers with preferred third-party financing sources.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S5	We also work with solar financiers who lease solar systems to our customers over 10 to 20 year periods.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S6	We handle some of the administrative processing for our customers that choose to use third-party financing or leasing.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P50_S7	Loss of preferred third-party financing and leasing sources for our customers could adversely affect our business as it would reduce funding alternatives available to homeowners seeking to install a solar system.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S0	Sales and Marketing Our conventional marketing program includes presentation booths at tradeshows and consumer shows, Internet search engine optimization, pay-per-click ad words, Internet banner advertisements, affiliate marketing programs, canvassing, community involvement initiatives and customer referral programs.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S1	To enhance our solar energy integration business by generating leads of potential solar energy system customers and promoting our brand awareness, we operate our Solar Living Center and maintain a robust website.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S2	Our website provides pricing tools, media programming, in-depth articles and product information, and how-to instructional content.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S3	We also receive new customer leads from the referrals of our satisfied customers, through our customer rewards and affinity programs, from designers and architects with whom we have worked on previous projects, and through the strength and longevity of our Real Goods Solar brand name and reputation.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S4	We believe that these attractive sources of leads lower our customer acquisition costs to below what we estimate they would be if we were to rely solely on traditional marketing methods such as print, radio, television and Internet search words.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S5	After we receive these high-quality leads, our inside sales representatives conduct an extensive telephone interview of the potential customer during which we determine, among other things, information about the customer s site, location, and solar exposure, and that the customer and any relevant family member or co-owner is genuinely interested in and able to finance the purchase of a solar energy system.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S6	We use this focused customer qualification process to identify which potential customers are most likely to respond positively to our direct sales efforts before we make a site visit to the customer s location.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S7	We then utilize our direct sales force to pursue these qualified leads.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P51_S8	This qualification process further lowers our customer acquisition costs because it narrows our customer leads and allows us to focus our direct sales efforts on highly targeted customers.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P52_S0	We own the Real Goods Solar Living Center, which is located on a 12-acre campus in Hopland, California, approximately 95 miles north of San Francisco.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P52_S1	The Solar Living Center is a demonstration site for the technology and culture of solar living and serves as a very effective source of qualified leads for solar installations.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P52_S2	In 2012, the Solar Living Center had over 150,000 visitors.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P52_S3	Since it opened in 1996, more than 2.5 million people have visited the Solar Living Center, and it has become one of the largest tourist attractions in Northern California throughout the year.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P53_S0	Our residential customers have historically shared a number of characteristics.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P53_S1	They tend to be college-educated homeowners, 30 to 65 years in age, high-income earners who are generally motivated both by environmental and economic reasons to install a solar energy system.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P54_S0	Our residential solar energy systems are generally 10kW or smaller in size, and our commercial solar energy systems are generally no larger than 1MW in size.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P55_S0	Our typical residential customer is connected to the utility grid.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P55_S1	Our commercial customers have included wineries, schools, apartment buildings, low income housing communities, churches and retail facilities.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P56_S0	Suppliers We do not manufacture solar PV modules, inverters or other components used in our solar energy systems, but purchase those components directly from manufacturers or, in some cases, from third-party distributors.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P56_S1	We purchase solar PV modules manufactured by Canadian Solar, SunPower and others.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P56_S2	We purchase inverters manufactured by SMA, Enphase and others.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P56_S3	We currently purchase the components used in our solar energy systems on a purchase order basis from a select group of manufacturers or suppliers.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P56_S4	If we are unable to purchase from any of these sources in the future, we do not believe we would have difficulty in securing alternative supply sources, because all of the components we use in our solar energy systems are available from a number of different sources.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P56_S5	With that said, the world-wide market for solar PV modules has from time to time experienced shortages of supply that have increased prices and affected availability.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S0	The solar energy industry is in its early stages of development and is highly fragmented, especially in the residential sector, consisting of many small, privately held companies with limited resources and operating histories but some of which benefit from operating efficiencies or low overhead requirements.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S1	A number of competitors exist in the California market, including companies such as REC Solar, Verengo and Solar City.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S2	Several of our competitors have expanded their market share in the California market by opening multiple offices within the state.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S3	We estimate that we are currently in the top ten residential solar energy system installers in California.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S4	In Colorado our competitors include Namaste Solar Electric, REC Solar and Solar City, but we are not aware of published data regarding competitive positions in Colorado.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S5	In the northeast, our competitors include Solar City, Sungevity, Trinity Solar and others, but we are not aware of published data regarding competitive position in that area.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P57_S6	We compete on factors such as brand recognition, quality of services and products, pricing, speed and quality of installation.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S0	Regulations Solar integrator services are subject to oversight and regulation by national and local ordinances, including building, zoning and fire codes, environmental protection regulations, utility interconnection requirements for metering and other rules and regulations.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S1	Our design and engineering teams design and install solar energy systems to comply with these varying standards as well as to minimize the installation and operating costs of each system.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S2	Our operations are also subject to generally applicable laws and regulations relating to discharge of materials into the environment and protection of the environment; however, because our operations do not typically involve any such discharge, there are no material effects on our business relating to our compliance with such environmental laws and regulations.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S3	We operate under and have registered the tradenames Real Goods , which was last renewed in 2004, and Real Goods Solar , which is pending a tradename application.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S4	We believe these tradenames are significant assets to our business.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S5	The Real Goods tradename registration is valid for ten years and we endeavor to maintain such registrations as valid and current by filing all required renewal forms when due.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P58_S6	In addition, we hold the copyright for most of the contents of the Solar Living Sourcebook.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P59_S0	We have historically experienced seasonality in our business, with the first quarter representing our slowest quarter of the year.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P59_S1	Additionally, the fourth quarter can be impacted by unfavorable weather in certain geographic regions, especially in the northeastern parts of the country.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P59_S2	Much of the seasonality in the business in previous quarters has been offset by changes in government activities as well as strong organic growth.
1425565_13_ITEM1_P59_S3	As of March 22, 2013, we had approximately 334 full-time and 9 part-time employees, including installation personnel.
