1425565_14_ITEM1_P0_S2	We offer turnkey services, including design, procurement, permitting, build-out, grid connection, financing referrals and warranty and customer satisfaction activities.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our solar energy systems use high-quality solar system components from tier-1 manufacturers such as Canadian Solar and Fronius for PV modules and inverters respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P0_S4	We use proven technologies and techniques to help customers achieve meaningful savings by reducing their utility costs and total cost of energy.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P0_S5	In addition, we help customers lower their emissions of carbon and reliance upon fossil fuel energy sources.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P0_S6	As part of our evolution and to participate in the broader solar value chain, we recently expanded the loan and lease finance options provided to our customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S0	We, including our predecessors, have over 35 years of experience in providing solar energy directly to end users.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S1	We have designed and installed over 19,000 residential and commercial solar systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S2	This makes us one of the most experienced and one of the largest downstream solar companies in the country.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S3	Presently we serve customers in the United States from offices located in ten states.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S4	In our history we have completed solar installations for customers in more than 30 states.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S5	Our goal is to continue to build upon our national presence to become one of the largest and most profitable residential and commercial solar energy integrators in the United States.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P1_S6	Our strategies to achieve this goal are:
1425565_14_ITEM1_P2_S0	Continue to expand into markets with favorable legislation and incentives for solar energy.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P2_S1	As jurisdictions adopt new, or improve existing, incentive programs that enhance the economics of solar energy systems, we intend to focus our sales and marketing efforts in those states and territories to increase our customer base.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	In addition to federal investment tax credits, many jurisdictions, including Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Hawaii, Massachusetts, Missouri, Nevada, New Jersey, New York and Puerto Rico have adopted legislation and incentives favorable to distributed solar energy production.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	Continue to drive growth through organic and acquisition efforts.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	The U.S. solar energy installation market is highly fragmented.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P5_S1	Our acquisition strategy is intended to consolidate markets and achieve economies of scale, increasing operating efficiencies and our competitive strengths.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P5_S2	Our organic growth strategy targets markets with favorable solar energy regulatory environments and is intended to leverage our historic presence in those markets.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	Continue to disrupt the centralized energy production model.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	The centralized production of energy reduces consumer choice and leads to increased costs during periods of peak demand.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P7_S1	Our objective of increasing distributed electrical energy production reduces reliance on utility energy providers and results in lower energy costs for the consumer.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	We believe that we have a number of advantages over our competitors.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P8_S1	Our competitors include other solar providers as well as electric utilities already serving our potential customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	Low barriers to switching to solar.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our approach includes design, engineering, financing referral, procurement, permitting and construction of the solar energy system.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P9_S2	Customers are able to transition to sustainable solar energy efficiently.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P10_S0	We have a highly experienced management team.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P10_S1	Our management team, including the members of our Board of Directors, has significant experience building national and international organizations.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S0	Our national footprint, with West Coast, East Coast and Midwest operations, allows us to offer solar energy systems at lower costs than our competitors through economies of scale.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S1	Description of our Services We offer turnkey solar energy services, including design, procurement, permitting, build-out, grid connection, financing referrals and warranty and customer satisfaction activities.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S2	We install residential and commercial systems that are generally between 3 kilowatts, or kW, and 1megawatt, or MW, output, with the average residential installation being approximately 6 kW output.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S3	We also on occasion install larger commercial projects in the 3-4 MW range.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S4	We also have the capability and have successfully completed larger projects for utility customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S5	We design and build our solar energy systems to meet each customer s individual needs and circumstances.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S6	We assess a customer s annual power requirements and average daily consumption rates in different seasons of the year to size the solar energy system and engineer its wiring.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S7	We assess the customer s roof size, configuration, and composition to determine the optimum location for the solar PV modules.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S8	We factor in information about the customer s electrical service territory and its rate structures and the customer s budget and preferred financing method, as well as the customer s aesthetic preferences.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S9	We also identify the relevant federal, state and local regulations, including building codes, which are important to the cost, operation and return on investment of the customer s solar energy system, as well as relevant tax rates and various other factors.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P11_S10	We assess this data using solar monitoring tools and analytical calculations, which enable us to design a solar energy system to a size and configuration that maximizes energy efficiency for each customer s circumstances.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P12_S0	We prepare final construction plans to obtain a building permit which is necessary for rebate processing.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P12_S1	We also provide customers with a return on investment analysis and determine the rebates and performance-based incentives that are available to each customer.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P13_S0	As soon as the building permit is approved, our installation professionals begin the installation by placing metal racking on the customer s roof (or by building a ground mount in certain situations), followed by installation of the solar PV modules, inverter(s) and the balance of systems components and safety equipment.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P13_S1	We do not custom manufacture solar PV modules or inverters, but rather purchase these manufactured components for incorporation into our constructed solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P13_S2	After the solar PV modules and inverter(s) are installed on the customer s home or business, we obtain a final inspection of the installation by the local building department, prepare and submit all rebate applications to the appropriate rebating jurisdiction and at the same time apply for the local utility company to interconnect the customer s solar energy system to the utility grid.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P14_S0	A basic solar energy system has no moving parts and consists of a number of solar PV modules wired together and mounted on a metal framing structure located either on our customer s roof or on a freestanding mounting structure, an inverter and the balance of systems and safety equipment necessary to connect the system to the customer s existing utility service.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P15_S0	We source solar PV modules from several primary manufacturers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P15_S1	These modules range in conversion efficiency from 14% to 19%.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P16_S0	Solar PV modules can be manufactured using different semiconductor materials, including mono- and poly-crystalline silicon, amorphous silicon, gallium arsenide, copper indium gallium selenide, or CIGS, and cadmium telluride.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P17_S0	Developments in solar PV technology have generated advances in the conversion efficiency of solar PV cells, reductions in manufacturing costs and improvements in manufacturing yields.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P18_S0	An inverter is an electronic device that converts the low-voltage DC power generated by solar PV modules to conventional 120-volt AC power used by standard household lights and appliances.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P18_S1	While an inverter may need to be replaced approximately 15 years after installation, other system components typically do not require replacement during the 20- to 25-year warranty period applicable to solar PV modules.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P19_S0	Individual solar energy systems are connected to the utility grid by an inverter, which also allows the excess electricity produced to flow into the grid, causing the customer s electric meter effectively to run backwards, to the credit of the customer s utility account, sometimes at standard retail prices.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P19_S1	A customer that has a grid-connected solar energy system draws energy from the grid through the conventional local utility when the sun is not shining, or when household energy consumption exceeds the solar energy system s energy generation capacity.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S0	Warranty Terms Most manufacturers of solar PV modules currently offer a 20- to 25-year transferable warranty of their products.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S1	We offer a 10-year parts and labor warranty, which covers property damage arising from the installation.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S2	We generally handle manufacturer warranty claims for solar PV modules as part of our customer service and we are typically reimbursed by the manufacturers for our labor and materials.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S3	Historically, our costs associated with warranty claims have been minimal.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S4	Financing While many of our customers choose to purchase their solar energy systems without the use of financing, we also connect our customers with preferred third-party financing sources.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S5	We presently offer a diverse array of financing options to our customers especially in the residential sector where in addition to third-party leasing solutions, we also offer a variety of loan options.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S6	Our diverse finance offerings allow us to provide solar power to our customers at prices that are economically attractive to their individual situation.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S7	In addition, maintaining a variety of financing sources allows us to source customer financing under the most favorable terms.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S8	We work with solar financing partners who provide long-term leases of solar systems to our customers for up to a 20-year period.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S9	The long term of the lease helps lower the monthly cost and such leases may also provide our customer with a no money down option.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P20_S10	Many customers find this option to be attractive in that the new combined monthly payments to their electric utility plus the solar lease payment can be less than the amount previously being paid monthly to their utility provider.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P21_S0	We handle some of the administrative processing for our customers that choose to use third-party financing or leasing.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P21_S1	The substantial knowledge we have gained in working with financing sources to market and facilitate sales to our customers has allowed us to increase our in-house financing capabilities and explore meaningful options to directly participate in the financing part of the solar value chain.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P21_S2	For instance, we recently expanded our finance offerings to commercial customers to include an in-house co-managed fund.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P21_S3	In addition, in the fourth quarter of 2013 and first quarter of 2014 we expanded our residential financing capabilities including the hiring of key personnel.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P21_S4	We believe that investments in these key areas will allow us to increase the value we provide to our customers, increase velocity in the sales cycle and allow us to participate in the long-term ownership potential of solar assets which we believe will also be beneficial to our shareholders.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our outside sales force works in the markets we serve and follows up on sales leads we receive.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P22_S1	The outside sales team visits potential customers in their homes, explaining the advantages of solar energy and answering customer questions.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our door-to-door sales efforts include engaging potential customers through door hangers and conversations, resulting in sales leads for our outside sales team.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P24_S0	Our e-sales and inside sales groups provide the opportunity to initially engage with potential customers without a site visit.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P24_S1	The e-sales and inside sales groups discuss the customer s interest in solar energy and compile data necessary to assess potential cost savings and costs to install the system.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P24_S2	We utilize electronic contracts and digital signatures within these teams.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S0	Our customer referral program is designed to be an effective and efficient method reaching new customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S1	Our program provides cash incentives to current customers to refer friends, relatives and co-workers to us.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S2	Our residential customers are homeowners interested in reducing electrical utility costs and switching to sustainable energy.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S3	Our residential solar energy systems are generally rooftop installations of less than 10kW in size.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S4	Our commercial customers come from a variety of industries including retail, manufacturing, service and municipal services.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S5	Our commercial solar energy systems may be roof mounted or ground mounted and are generally between 250 kW and 1 MW in size.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S6	Suppliers Our solar energy systems utilize solar panels and inverters purchased from several manufacturers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S7	We negotiate pricing based on quantity purchased and payment terms.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S8	We purchase major components as needed and do not have long-term or volume commitments with suppliers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S9	Competition We primarily compete with other solar companies providing similar services.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P25_S10	These companies vary in size and capability and our larger competitors include Solar City and Verengo in the residential space and companies such as Borrego, REC Solar, and groSolar in the commercial space.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P26_S0	The solar industry as a whole has rapidly evolved in recent years.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P26_S1	The competitive landscape changed substantially over the past year and is expected to continue to rapidly change.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P26_S2	For instance, electric utilities are our competition, both as incumbent power providers and also as recent entrants into the downstream solar market.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P26_S3	Additional recent new competitors also include traditional third party solar finance companies such as SunRun.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P26_S4	Historically they did not compete directly with us in the downstream solar market but recent acquisitions and establishment of new channel relationships which will likely make them competitors in the future.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P26_S5	We believe we understand these rapidly changing dynamics and are well positioned to adapt our sales and marketing, customer finance and delivery methods and our business model to maintain and grow our position in the market.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S0	Regulations We work with local electrical utilities to obtain permission to operate and interconnection for our customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S1	Interconnection is, generally, a standard agreement between the customer and the utility.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S2	There are no additional regulatory approvals required following interconnection approval.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S3	We employ a team of administrators who work with utilities to achieve interconnection approval for our customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S4	We are subject to several federal, state and local laws and regulations governing safety on our job sites.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S5	We employ a safety professional to ensure we remain in compliance with such laws and regulation.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S6	Many of our municipal and government projects are subject to prevailing wage requirements.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S7	We have registered and operate under the tradenames Real Goods , Real Goods Solar and RGS Energy .
1425565_14_ITEM1_P27_S8	Registrations are valid for ten years and we maintain registrations by filing all required renewal application and fees when due.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P28_S0	We have historically experienced seasonality in our business, with the first quarter representing our slowest quarter of the year.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P28_S1	Additionally, the fourth quarter can be impacted by unfavorable weather in certain geographic regions, especially in the northeastern and Midwestern parts of the United States.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P29_S0	Employees As of March 21, 2014, we had approximately 488 full-time and 11 part-time employees.
1425565_14_ITEM1_P29_S1	None of our employees are represented by a labor union or subject to a collective bargaining agreement.

1425565_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	These risks and uncertainties include those risks described below of which we are presently aware.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Historical results are not necessarily an indication of the future results.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Cautionary statements below discuss important factors that could cause our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows to be materially adversely affected.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Risk Factors Related to our Business and Industry The reduction, elimination or expiration of government subsidies and economic incentives for solar energy systems could reduce the demand for our products.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	U.S. federal, state and local government bodies and utilities provide incentives to end users, distributors, system integrators and manufacturers of solar energy systems to promote solar electricity in the form of rebates, tax credits and other financial incentives such as system performance payments and payments for renewable energy credits associated with renewable energy generation.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P2_S1	These incentives enable us to lower the price we charge our customers for solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P2_S2	However, these incentives may expire on a particular date, end when the allocated funding is exhausted, or be reduced or terminated as solar energy adoption rates increase.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P2_S3	These reductions or terminations often occur without warning.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The federal government currently offers a 30% investment tax credit under Section 48(a)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, or the Federal ITC, for the installation of certain solar power facilities until December 31, 2016.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P3_S1	This credit is due to adjust to 10% in 2017.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P3_S2	In addition, applicable authorities may adjust or decrease incentives from time to time or include provisions for minimum domestic content requirements or other requirements to qualify for these incentives.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P3_S3	The reduction, elimination or expiration of such incentives or delays or interruptions in the implementation of favorable federal or state laws could substantially increase the cost of our systems to our customers, resulting in a significant reduction in demand for our solar energy systems, which would negatively impact our business.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P3_S4	We prepare and submit paperwork on behalf of our customers to obtain applicable incentive payments and reimbursement and the failure to successfully do so may decrease our revenue and profitability.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We, in some instances, prepare and submit the necessary paperwork on behalf of our customers to obtain applicable incentive payments and reimbursements.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P4_S1	The processing of such paperwork is generally subject to rigid and formal compliance procedures.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P4_S2	In addition, such processing may be time consuming and add significant cost and administrative burden.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We may price our products assuming that we will be successful in obtaining available incentive payments and reimbursements.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P5_S1	There can be no assurance that we will be able to process necessary paperwork in a timely manner and successfully obtain all incentive payments and reimbursements available to us or to our customers.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If we are unsuccessful in doing so, our revenue and sales margin will be negatively impacted.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P5_S3	Adverse general economic conditions could have a material impact on our business.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P5_S4	Adverse overall economic conditions that impact consumer spending could impact our results of operations.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P5_S5	Future economic conditions affecting disposable income such as employment levels, consumer confidence, credit availability, spending on housing, business conditions, stock market volatility, weather conditions, acts of terrorism, threats of war, and interest and tax rates could reduce consumer spending or cause consumers to shift their spending away from our products.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	While many economic indicators have improved recently, activity in many areas of the general U.S. economy remain sluggish.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P6_S1	If the economic conditions continue to be adverse or worsen, we may experience material adverse impacts on our business, operating results and financial condition.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Such impacts may increase our cost of funding and limit our access to some of our traditional sources of liquidity, including both secured and unsecured borrowings.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Increases in funding costs and limitations on our access to liquidity could have a negative impact on our earnings and our ability to drive our growth strategies.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	In addition, in the past, the deteriorating general economic conditions in the United States have caused a drop in consumer spending in general, and discretionary spending in particular.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P7_S1	If these were to occur again in the future, these dynamics may also adversely impact the solar sector.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Our business prospects could be harmed if solar energy is not widely adopted or sufficient demand for solar energy systems does not develop or takes longer to develop than we anticipate.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The solar energy market is at a relatively early stage of development.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P8_S1	The extent to which solar energy will be widely adopted and the extent to which demand for solar energy systems will increase are uncertain.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P8_S2	If solar energy does not achieve widespread adoption or demand for solar energy systems fails to develop sufficiently, we may be unable to grow our business at the rate we desire.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P8_S3	In addition, demand for solar energy systems in our targeted markets may not develop or may develop to a lesser extent or more slowly than we anticipate.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Many factors may affect the demand for solar energy systems, including the following:
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	deregulation of the electric power industry and the broader energy industry.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P9_S1	A drop in the retail price of conventional energy or non-solar renewable energy sources may negatively impact our business.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P9_S2	The demand for our solar energy systems depends in part on the price of conventional energy, which affects return on investment resulting from the purchase of solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Fluctuations in economic and market conditions that impact the prices of conventional and non-solar renewable energy sources could cause the demand for solar energy systems to decline, which would have a negative impact on our business .
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Existing regulations and policies pertaining to electricity pricing and technical interconnection of customer-owned electricity generation and changes to these regulations and policies may deter the purchase and use of solar energy systems and negatively impact development of the solar energy industry.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The market for solar energy systems is heavily influenced by foreign, federal, state and local government regulations and policies concerning the electric utility industry, as well as policies adopted by electric utilities.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P10_S1	These regulations and policies often relate to electricity pricing and technical interconnection of customer-owned electricity generation.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P10_S2	For example, the vast majority of states have a regulatory policy known as net energy metering, or net metering.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P10_S3	Net metering typically allows our customers to interconnect their on-site solar energy systems to the utility grid and offset their utility electricity purchases by receiving a bill credit at the utility s retail rate for energy generated by their solar energy system that is exported to the grid and not consumed on-site.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P10_S4	In this way, the customer pays for the net energy used or receives a credit at the retail rate if more energy is produced than consumed.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Metering caps currently exist in certain jurisdictions, which limit the aggregate amount of power that may be sold by solar power generators into the electric grid.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P11_S1	These regulations and policies have been modified in the past and may be modified in the future in ways that could deter purchases of solar energy systems and investment in the research and development of solar energy technology.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Without a mandated regulatory exception for solar energy systems, utility customers are often charged interconnection or standby fees for putting distributed power generation on the electric utility grid.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Such fees could increase the cost to our customers of using solar energy systems and make them less desirable, thereby harming our business, operating results and financial condition.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P12_S2	In addition, electricity generated by solar energy systems competes primarily with expensive peak hour electricity rates rather than with the less expensive average price of electricity.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Modifications to the peak hour pricing policies of utilities, such as to a flat rate, would require solar energy systems to achieve lower prices in order to compete with the price of utility generated electricity.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P12_S4	Existing regulations, and changes to such regulations, may present technical, regulatory and economic barriers to the installation of solar energy systems, which may significantly reduce demand for our solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The installation of solar energy systems is subject to oversight and regulation under local ordinances; building, zoning and fire codes; environmental protection regulation; utility interconnection requirements for metering; and other rules and regulations.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P13_S1	We attempt to keep up-to-date about these requirements on a national, state and local level and must design and install our solar energy systems to comply with varying standards.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Certain jurisdictions may have ordinances that prevent or increase the cost of installation of our solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P14_S1	In addition, new government regulations or utility policies pertaining to the installation of solar energy systems are unpredictable and may result in significant additional expenses or delays, which could cause a significant reduction in demand for solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P15_S0	For some of our projects, we recognize revenue on system installations on a percentage-of-completion basis and payments are due upon the achievement of contractual milestones, and any delay or cancellation of a project could adversely affect our business.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P15_S1	For some of our projects, we recognize revenue on a percentage-of-completion basis and, as a result, our revenue from these installations is driven by the performance of our contractual obligations.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P15_S2	The time it takes to execute our contractual obligations may impact the amount of revenue recognized in a particular period.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Timelines can be adversely impacted by weather, governmental agencies, utilities and customer requirements.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P16_S1	In addition, certain customer contracts may include payment milestones due at specified points during a project.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Although we generally build payment terms that provide for positive cash flow, delays in project execution or customer payments could adversely affect our business and cash flows.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Our sales and installations are subject to seasonality of customer demand and weather conditions which are outside of our control.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Our sales are subject to the seasonality of when customers buy solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P17_S3	We experience spikes in orders in the Spring and Summer months, which due to lead time result in installations and revenue increasing during the Summer and Fall.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P17_S4	Tax incentives can generate additional backlog prior to the end of the year, depending upon the incentive available and the tax appetite of the customer.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Our ability to construct systems outdoors can be impacted by inclement weather, which can be most prominent in our geographic installation regions during the first and fourth quarters of the year.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P18_S1	As a result of these factors, our first quarter is generally our slowest quarter of the year.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P18_S2	If unexpected natural events occur and we are unable to manage our cash flow through these seasonal factors, there could be a negative impact on our financial position, liquidity, results of operation and cash flow.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P18_S3	Our inability to respond to changing technologies and issues presented by new technologies could harm our business.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The solar energy industry is subject to technological change.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P19_S1	If we rely on products and technologies that are not attractive to customers, or if we are unable to respond appropriately to changing technologies and changes in product function and quality, we may not be successful in capturing or retaining a significant market share.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P19_S2	In addition, any new technologies utilized in our solar energy systems may not perform as expected or as desired, in which event our adoption of such products or technologies may harm our business.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We derive the majority of the revenue from our solar energy integration services from sales in west coast and northeast states.

1425565_14_ITEM1A_P60_S4	Further, pursuant to the terms of the Shareholders Agreement entered into in connection with the closing of the Alteris merger, Riverside currently has the right to designate two individuals for appointment or nomination to our board of directors.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P60_S5	Because of Riverside s voting rights and its ability to designate individuals for appointment or nomination to our board of directors, Riverside will be able to exert influence over our company and matters requiring approval by our shareholders, including the election of directors, increasing our authorized capital stock, financing activities, a merger or sale of our assets and the number of shares authorized for issuance under our 2008 Long-Term Incentive Plan.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P60_S6	Accordingly, shares of our Class A common stock may be worth less than they would be if Riverside did not maintain voting significance over us.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P60_S7	Riverside is not prohibited from selling a significant interest in our company to a third party and may do so without shareholder approval and without providing for a purchase of other shares of our Class A common stock.

1425565_14_ITEM1A_P60_S12	The historical financial information in our audited and unaudited consolidated financial statements may not be indicative of what our results of operations, financial position, changes in equity and cash flows would have been had we been a separate stand-alone entity during the periods presented, or what they will be in the future.
1425565_14_ITEM1A_P60_S13	We have not made adjustments to reflect many significant changes that occurred in our cost structure, funding and operations as a result of our separation from Gaiam, including changes in our employee base, changes in our tax structure, potential increased costs associated with reduced economies of scale and increased costs associated with being a publicly traded, stand-alone company, such as audit fees, directors and officers insurance costs and compliance costs.

Overview We are a leading provider of turnkey commercial and residential solar energy solutions, with more than 19,000 solar systems in place.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S2	We also have more than 35 years of experience in solar energy, beginning with the sale in 1978 of the first solar PV panels in the United States.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S3	With 16 offices across the West, Midwest and the Northeast, we are one of the larger solar energy installers in the U.S. in the residential and commercial sectors.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S4	However, there are market participants, especially in the utility-size solar systems, who are much larger than us.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S5	Our revenue primarily results from the installation of solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S6	We also derive a portion of our revenue from the retail sale of renewable energy products.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S7	Our expenses primarily consist of labor costs, costs of solar modules, invertors, balance of systems and other direct costs associated with solar system installation, and related sales and marketing and general and administrative costs.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S8	We continue to expect strong demand for both residential and commercial solar installations, despite the overall economic weakness in the United States.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P1_S9	As one of the few solar installers with a relatively strong national footprint, we expect to capitalize on our market position and the expanding U.S. solar industry.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	Mergers and Acquisitions Earth Friendly Energy Group Holdings, LLC d/b/a Alteris Renewables We obtained financial control, through an Agreement and Plan of Merger, of 100% of the voting equity interests of Earth Friendly Energy Group Holdings, LLC d/b/a Alteris Renewables ( Alteris ) on June 21, 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	The total consideration transferred was approximately $21.7 million and was comprised of 8.7 million shares of our Class A common stock, valued at $21.6 million based on our Class A common stock closing market price of $2.48 per share on June 21, 2011, and $0.1 million worth of replacement share-based payment awards attributable to services rendered prior to the acquisition date.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	We purchased certain assets and assumed certain current liabilities of Syndicated Solar, Inc. ( Syndicated ) through an Asset Purchase Agreement on August 9, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	The total consideration transferred was approximately $2.4 million and was comprised of 400,000 shares of our Class A common stock, valued at $916,000 based on our Class A common stock closing market price of $2.29 per share on August 9, 2013, approximately, $1.2 million of liabilities assumed in excess of assets acquired and cash of $250,000.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	In addition the fair value of liabilities assumed exceeded the fair value of assets acquired by $1.2 million.

Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, or GAAP.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	We base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P5_S2	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P5_S3	We have identified the following to be critical accounting policies whose application have a material impact on our reported results of operations, and which involve a higher degree of complexity, as they require us to make judgments and estimates about matters that are inherently uncertain.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue consists primarily of solar energy system installation fees.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	We recognize revenue from fixed price contracts using either the completed contract or percentage-of-completion method, based on the size of the energy system installation.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	We recognize revenue for fixed price contracts from energy system installations of less than 100 kilowatts, or kW, when the installation is substantially complete, while we recognize revenue from energy system installations equal to or greater than 100 kW on a percentage-of-completion basis, measured by the percentage of contract costs incurred to date to total estimated costs for each contract.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	The percentage-of-completion method involves estimates of progress.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	We believe the best indicator of progress toward completion of the project is costs incurred to date as a percentage of estimated actual costs.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	Allowances for Doubtful Accounts We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of our customers to make required payments.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	We make estimates of the collectability of our accounts receivable by analyzing historical bad debts, specific customer creditworthiness, and current economic trends.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	If the financial condition of our customers were to deteriorate such that their ability to make payments to us was impaired, additional allowances could be required.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	Inventory Inventory consists primarily of solar energy system components (such as solar panels and inverters) located in various warehouse facilities and finished goods held for sale at our Solar Living Center located in Hopland, California.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	We state our inventory at the lower of cost (first-in, first-out method) or market.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P9_S2	We identify the inventory items to be written down for obsolescence based on the item s current sales status and condition.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P9_S3	We write down discontinued or slow moving inventories based on an estimate of the markdown to retail price needed to sell through our current stock level of the inventories.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	Goodwill Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase consideration over the estimated fair value of assets acquired less liabilities assumed in a business acquisition.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently if impairment indicators arise.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P10_S2	Since we operate in only one business segment, we assess impairment at the Company level.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P10_S3	We have the option of first assessing qualitative factors to determine whether events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the fair value of the Company is less than its carrying amount.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P10_S4	If it is determined that the fair value of the Company is more likely than not greater than its carrying amount, then the two-step impairment test is unnecessary.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	If it is determined that the two-step impairment test is necessary, then for step one, we compare the estimated fair value of the Company with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	If the estimated fair value of the Company exceeds its carrying amount, we consider the Company s goodwill not impaired.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	If the carrying amount of the Company exceeds its estimated fair value, we perform the second step of the goodwill impairment test to measure the amount of impairment loss.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	We use either a comparable market approach, traditional present value method, or some combination thereof to test for potential impairment.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	The use of present value techniques requires us to make estimates and judgments about our future cash flows.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	These cash flow forecasts will be based on assumptions that are consistent with the plans and estimates we use to manage our business.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	The process of evaluating the potential impairment of goodwill is highly subjective and requires significant judgment at many points during the analysis.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	Application of alternative assumptions and definitions could yield significantly different results.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	We account for the acquisition of a controlling interest in a business using the purchase method.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	In determining the estimated fair value of certain acquired assets and liabilities, we make assumptions based upon historical and other relevant information and, in some cases, independent expert appraisals.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	Assumptions may be incomplete, and unanticipated events and circumstances may occur that could affect the validity of such assumptions, estimates, or actual results.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	Share-Based Compensation We recognize compensation cost for share-based awards based on the estimated fair value of the award on date of grant.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	We measure compensation cost at the grant date based on the estimated fair value of the award and recognize compensation cost upon the probable attainment of a specified performance condition or over a service period.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	the fair value for purposes of accounting and disclosures.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	In calculating this fair value, there are certain highly subjective assumptions that we use, consisting of estimated market value of our stock, the expected life of the option, risk-free interest rate, dividend yield, and volatility.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	The use of different estimates for any one of these assumptions could have a material impact on the amount of calculated compensation expense.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	Income Taxes We provide for income taxes pursuant to the liability method.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	The liability method requires recognition of deferred income taxes based on temporary differences between financial reporting and income tax bases of assets and liabilities, using current enacted income tax rates and regulations.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P17_S2	These differences will result in taxable income or deductions in future years when the reported amount of the asset or liability is recovered or settled, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P17_S3	Considerable judgment is required in determining when these events may occur and whether recovery of an asset, including the utilization of a net operating loss carryforward prior to its expiration, is more likely than not.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P17_S4	We recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P17_S5	We measure the tax benefits recognized in the consolidated financial statements from such a position based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate resolution.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	The application of income tax law is inherently complex.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	Laws and regulations in this area are voluminous and are often ambiguous.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	As such, we are required to make many subjective assumptions and judgments regarding our income tax exposures.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P18_S3	Interpretations of and guidance surrounding income tax law and regulations change over time and may result in changes to our subjective assumptions and judgments which can materially affect amounts recognized in our consolidated financial statements.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	Results of Operations Year Ended December 31, 2013 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2012 Net revenue .
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	Net revenue increased $8.5 million, or 9.1%, to $101.3 million during 2013 from $92.9 million during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S2	The increase in revenue reflects an increase in solar systems constructed to a record 29.7 megawatts in 2013 from 26.6 megawatts in 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S3	Gross profit decreased $722,000, or 3.1%, to $22.3 million during 2013 from $23.0 million during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S4	As a percentage of net revenue, gross profit decreased to 22.0% during 2013 from 24.8% during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S5	The decline in gross profit reflects competitive pricing pressure as well as the adverse impact of inclement weather on labor utilization efficiency in the four quarters of 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S6	Selling and operating expenses decreased $4.1 million, or 13.9%, to $25.7 million during 2013 from $29.8 million during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S7	As a percentage of net revenue, selling and operating expenses decreased to 25.3% during 2013 from 32.1% during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S8	The decrease in selling and operating expenses is attributable to consolidation of functions in our Colorado office and resulting reductions in headcount.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S9	General and administrative expenses decreased $2.0 million, or 21.9%, to $7.0 million during 2013 from $8.9 million during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S10	As a percentage of net revenue, general and administrative expenses decreased to 6.9% during 2013 from 9.6% during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S11	The decrease in general and administrative expenses is due to consolidation of back-office functions in our Colorado office and resulting decreases in headcount.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S12	Acquisition and other costs were $2.0 million during 2013 and were the result of our acquisition of Syndicated, the acquisition of Mercury, which closed on January 14, 2014.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S13	Net interest income was $1.1 million for 2013 The 2013 amount was impacted by a non-cash benefit of approximately $2.0 million recorded as interest income arising from the application of fair value accounting to the common stock warrant liability of approximately $15.1 million at December 31, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S14	Excluding the benefit, interest expense was approximately $0.9 million for 2013 compared to approximately $0.8 million for 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S15	The increase reflects interest charges related to the revolving line of credit.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S16	Income tax expense was $58,000 for 2013, representing state income taxes not offset by the loss from operations.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P19_S17	As a result of the above factors, our net loss was $11.3 million, or $0.38 per share, during 2013 compared to $47.2 million, or $1.77 per share, during 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	Year Ended December 31, 2012 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2011 Net revenue .
1425565_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	Net revenue decreased $16.4 million, or 15.0%, to $92.9 million during 2012 from $109.3 million during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P20_S2	The revenue decline was primarily attributable to the direct supplying to customers by financing companies of certain components used in residential installation.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P20_S3	Sourcing of such components in conjunction with the associated financing allowed residential customers to take advantage of certain expiring tax benefits, and are referred to as safe harbor installations and amounted to $9.6 million in 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	While we recognize lower revenue from safe harbor installations, our gross margins are similar to non-safe harbor installations.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	In addition, revenue from commercial customer installations declined by approximately $6.0 million due to a lower average sales price per watt installed.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S2	Gross profit decreased $4.8 million, or 17.3%, to $23.0 million during 2012 from $27.9 million during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S3	As a percentage of net revenue, gross profit decreased to 24.8% during 2012 from 25.5% during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S4	The decrease in gross profit was due to a higher proportion of commercial installations, which have lower gross profit margins than residential installations, as well as lower year over year average margins on those commercial installations.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S5	Selling and operating expenses increased $6.2 million, or 26.1%, to $29.8 million during 2012 from $23.6 million during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S6	As a percentage of net revenue, selling and operating expenses increased to 32.1% during 2012 from 21.6% during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S7	The increase in selling and operating expenses is attributable to costs associated with the integration of Alteris that resulted in the centralization of functions in our Colorado corporate head office.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S8	General and administrative expenses increased $4.8 million, or 116.8%, to $8.9 million during 2012 from $4.1 million during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S9	As a percentage of net revenue, general and administrative expenses increased to 9.6% during 2012 from 3.8% during 2011.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S10	The increase in general and administrative expenses is due to investments in our Louisville, Colorado head office, in management and leadership talent, and in shared services personnel subsequent to the Alteris merger, and executive recruiting fees.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S11	Acquisition-related costs were $2.4 million during 2011 and were the result of our acquisition of Alteris.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P21_S12	Goodwill and other asset impairments were $22.0 million for 2012 and were comprised of noncash impairment charges of $19.7 million for goodwill, $2.1 million for property and equipment, and $0.2 million for other intangibles.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	We estimated the fair value of our business for the intangibles impairment analysis based on the quoted market price for our Class A common stock (level one input of the fair value hierarchy), as adjusted by our judgmental qualitative factors (level three of the fair value hierarchy).
1425565_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	The impairment of our property and equipment was based on market place property comparables (level two of the fair value hierarchy).
1425565_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	These noncash impairments were necessitated by the trading price of our Class A common stock, recent operating losses, and our financial forecasts.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P22_S3	Income tax expense was $8.7 million for 2012 and includes a $16.1 million noncash charge for the establishment of a valuation allowance for all of our net deferred tax assets.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P22_S4	As a result of the above factors, our net loss was $47.2 million, or $1.77 per share, during 2012 compared to $1.9 million, or $0.08 per share, during 2011.

1425565_14_ITEM7_P23_S1	These capital requirements depend on numerous factors, including business acquisitions, the ability to attract new solar energy system installation customers, market acceptance of our product offerings, the cost of ongoing upgrades to our product offerings, the level of expenditures for sales and marketing, the level of investment in support systems and facilities and other factors.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P23_S2	The timing and amount of these capital requirements are variable and may fluctuate from time to time.
1425565_14_ITEM7_P23_S3	To the extent we have or can arrange available capital, we plan to continue to pursue acquisitions and other opportunities to expand our sales territories, technologies, and products and increase our sales and marketing programs as needed.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	Report of Independent registered public accounting firm To the Board of Directors and Shareholders of Real Goods Solar, Inc.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S1	Louisville, Colorado We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Real Goods Solar, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in shareholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three year period ended December 31, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S2	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S4	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S6	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S7	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P0_S8	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P1_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P6_S1	Principles of Consolidation, Organization and Nature of Operations Real Goods Solar, Inc. ( RGS or Company ) is a leading residential and commercial solar energy engineering, procurement, and construction firm.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P6_S2	The Company was incorporated in Colorado on January 29, 2008 under the name Real Goods Solar, Inc.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P6_S3	The Company s initial public offering of common stock occurred on May 7, 2008.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P6_S4	On January 15, 2014, the Company began doing business as RGS Energy and changed its ticker symbol to RGSE on February 24, 2014.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Real Goods Solar and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P7_S1	RGS has prepared the accompanying consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States, or GAAP, which include the Company s accounts and those of its subsidiaries.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P7_S2	Intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Company has included the results of operations of acquired companies from the effective date of acquisition.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P8_S1	Liquidity Update At December 31, 2013, the Company s cash balance was $12.4 million.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P8_S2	The Company s related party debt of $2.7 million owed to Gaiam, Inc.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P8_S3	( Gaiam ) was repaid on November 5, 2013 while its related party debt of $4.15 million owed to Riverside Renewable Energy Investments, LLC ( Riverside ) was extended; $1.0 million is due April 26, 2014, $3.0 million is due September 3, 2014 and $150,000 is due October 29, 2014.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P8_S4	During September, 2013, RGS entered into the Fifth Loan Modification Agreement with Silicon Valley Bank ( SVB ), which extended the revolving line of credit maturity date to September 29, 2014 and provided RGS with a $2.0 million term loan.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P9_S1	The Company regained compliance as of February 21, 2013.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	Cash Cash represents demand deposit accounts with financial institutions that are denominated in U.S. dollars.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses resulting from the inability of its customers to make required payments.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	The Company makes estimates of the collectability of its accounts receivable by analyzing historical bad debts, specific customer creditworthiness and current economic trends.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P10_S3	The allowance for doubtful accounts was $618,000 and $1.1 million at December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P10_S4	If the financial condition of our customers or the public utilities or financing companies were to deteriorate such that their ability to make payments to us was impaired, additional allowances could be required.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	Inventory Inventory consists primarily of solar energy system components (such as solar panels and inverters) located at the Company s various warehouses and finished goods held for sale at its Solar Living Center located in Hopland, California.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	RGS states inventory at the lower of cost (first-in, first-out method) or market.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P11_S2	The Company identifies the inventory items to be written down for obsolescence based on the item s current sales status and condition.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P11_S3	The Company writes down discontinued or slow moving inventories based on an estimate of the markdown to retail price needed to sell through its current stock level of the inventories.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P11_S4	At December 31, 2013 and 2012, the Company estimated obsolete or slow-moving inventory to be $400,000 and $700,000, respectively, net of estimated reserves.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	Property and Equipment The Company states property and equipment at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P12_S1	Depreciation of property and equipment is computed on the straight-line method over estimated useful lives, generally three to twenty years.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	RGS amortizes leasehold and building improvements over the shorter of the estimated useful lives of the assets or the remaining term of the lease or remaining life of the building, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	Goodwill and Other Intangibles Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase consideration over the estimated fair value of assets acquired less liabilities assumed in a business acquisition.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently if impairment indicators arise.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P14_S2	As RGS operates in only one business segment, it assesses impairment at the Company level.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	The Company has the option of first assessing qualitative factors to determine whether events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the fair value of the Company is less than its carrying amount.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P15_S1	If it is determined that the fair value of the Company is more likely than not greater than its carrying amount, then the two-step impairment test is unnecessary.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	If it is determined that the two-step impairment test is necessary, then for step one, RGS compares the estimated fair value of the Company with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P16_S1	If the estimated fair value of the Company exceeds its carrying amount, the Company s goodwill considered not impaired.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P16_S2	If the carrying amount of the Company exceeds its estimated fair value, the second step of the goodwill impairment test to measure the amount of impairment loss is performed.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P16_S3	The Company uses either a comparable market approach, traditional present value method, or some combination thereof to test for potential impairment.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	The use of present value techniques requires us to make estimates and judgments about future cash flows.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P17_S1	These cash flow forecasts are based on assumptions that are consistent with the plans and estimates RGS uses to manage its business.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	The process of evaluating the potential impairment of goodwill is highly subjective and requires significant judgment at many points during the analysis.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P18_S1	Application of alternative assumptions and definitions could yield significantly different results.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	The Company s goodwill balances were $1.9 million and zero at December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively, and other intangibles balances were $480,000 and zero at December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P19_S1	The other intangibles are comprised of backlog acquired from Syndicated Solar, Inc. and will be amortized to selling and operating expenses over a period of less than 12 months.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P19_S2	The Company had impaired all goodwill and other intangibles at September 30, 2012 (see Note 4.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P19_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2012, amortization expense was $0.2 million.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P19_S4	During the year ended December 31, 2013, the Company recorded $1.9 million of goodwill as a result of the acquisition of Syndicated Solar, Inc.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P19_S5	There is no amortization expense recorded for the year ended December 31, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	Purchase Accounting RGS accounts for business acquisitions using the purchase method.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	In determining the estimated fair value of certain acquired assets and liabilities, the Company makes assumptions based upon historical and other relevant information and, in some cases, reports of independent valuation experts.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P21_S1	Assumptions may be incomplete, and unanticipated events and circumstances may occur that could affect the validity of such assumptions, estimates, or actual results.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	As a result of the acquisition of Syndicated and Mercury Energy, Inc., RGS incurred acquisition-related costs that are required to be expensed as incurred, including subsequent adjustments to valuation entries made at the time of the acquisition.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	For the twelve months ended December 31, 2013, the Company recorded $2.0 million of such costs.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	Revenue Recognition Revenue are derived primarily from contracts for the installation of solar energy systems.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	RGS recognizes revenue from fixed price contracts using either the completed contract or percentage-of-completion method, based on the size of the energy system installation.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	RGS recognizes revenue from energy system installations of less than 100 kilowatts, or kW, when the installation is substantially complete and recognizes revenue from energy system installations equal to or greater than 100 kW on a percentage-of-completion basis, measured by the percentage of contract costs incurred to date to total estimated costs for each contract.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P24_S2	The Company recognizes amounts billed to customers for shipping and handling as revenue at the same time that the revenues arising from the product sale are recognized.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P24_S3	RGS includes shipping and handling costs, which were approximately $500,000, $500,000, and $100,000 for 2013, 2012, and 2011, respectively, in selling and operating expense along with other fulfillment costs.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P24_S4	The assets Costs in excess of billings on uncompleted contracts and Deferred costs on uncompleted contracts represent costs incurred plus estimated earnings in excess of amounts billed on percentage-of-completion method contracts and costs incurred but deferred until recognition of the related contract revenue on completed-method contracts, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P24_S5	The liability Billings in excess of costs on uncompleted contracts represents billings in excess of related costs and earned profit on percentage-of-completion method contracts.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	RGS bills our large installation customers for contract performance progress according to milestones defined in their respective contracts.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	The prerequisite for billing is the completion of an application and certificate of payment form as per the contract, which is done after each month end.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	Unbilled receivables were immaterial at December 31, 2013 and 2012.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P26_S2	Deferred revenue consists of solar energy system installation fees billed to customers for projects which are not yet completed as on the balance sheet date.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	Allocation of Costs Historically, Gaiam provided RGS with administrative, technical accounting advisory, public financial reporting and related office services under the Intercorporate Services Agreement.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	During 2013, the Company s reliance on Gaiam for services provided under the Intercorporate Services Agreement decreased to the point that RGS and Gaiam terminated the agreement on December 19, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P27_S2	The accompanying financial statements include an allocation of these expenses.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P27_S3	The allocation is based on a combination of factors, including revenue and operating expenses.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P27_S4	The Company believes the allocation methodologies used are reasonable and result in an appropriate allocation of costs incurred by Gaiam and its subsidiaries on the Company s behalf.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P27_S5	However, these allocations may not be indicative of the cost of future services as the company operates on a standalone basis.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	Share-Based Compensation RGS recognizes compensation expense for share-based awards based on the estimated fair value of the award on date of grant.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	The Company measures compensation cost at the grant date fair value of the award and recognizes compensation expense based on the probable attainment of a specified performance condition or over a service period.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P28_S2	The Company uses the Black-Scholes option valuation model to estimate the fair value for purposes of accounting and disclosures.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P28_S3	In estimating this fair value, certain assumptions are used (see Note 12.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P28_S4	Share-Based Compensation), consisting of the expected life of the option, risk-free interest rate, dividend yield, volatility and forfeiture rate.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P28_S5	The use of different estimates for any one of these assumptions could have a material impact on the amount of reported compensation expense.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	Income Taxes RGS provides for income taxes pursuant to the liability method.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	The liability method requires recognition of deferred income taxes based on temporary differences between financial reporting and income tax bases of assets and liabilities, using current enacted income tax rates and regulations.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P29_S2	These differences will result in taxable income or deductions in future years when the reported amount of the asset or liability is recovered or settled, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P29_S3	Considerable judgment is required in determining when these events may occur and whether recovery of an asset is more likely than not.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	The Company s effective tax rate remains fairly consistent.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	RGS has significant net operating loss carryforwards and will re-evaluate at the end of each reporting period whether it expects it is more likely than not that the deferred tax assets will be fully recoverable through the reversal of taxable temporary differences in future years as a result of normal business activities.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P30_S2	The Company has agreed under our tax sharing agreement with Gaiam to make payments to Gaiam as RGS utilizes certain of its net operating losses in the future (see Note 13.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P30_S3	The Company recognizes the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P30_S4	RGS measures the tax benefits recognized in the consolidated financial statements from such a position based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon ultimate resolution.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	The application of income tax law is inherently complex.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P31_S1	Laws and regulations in this area are voluminous and are often ambiguous.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P31_S2	As such, RGS is required to make many subjective assumptions and judgments regarding its income tax exposures.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P31_S3	Interpretations of and guidance surrounding income tax law and regulations change over time and may result in changes to the Company s subjective assumptions and judgments which can materially affect amounts recognized in its consolidated balance sheets and statements of operations.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	The result of the reassessment of the Company s tax positions did not have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	RGS federal and state tax returns for all years after 2009 are subject to future examination by tax authorities for all our tax jurisdictions.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P32_S2	The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to income tax matters in interest expense and general and administration expenses, respectively.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	Net Loss Per Share RGS computes net loss per share by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding for the period.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	Diluted net loss per share reflects the potential dilution that could occur if options or warrants to issue shares of the Company s Class A common stock were exercised.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P33_S2	Weighted average common share equivalents of 7,012,000, 2,173,000 and 1,262,000 shares have been omitted from net loss per share for 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively, as they are anti-dilutive.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P33_S3	The following table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted net income (loss) per share: Concentration of Risk RGS has a potential concentration of credit risk in our accounts receivable in that two financing companies that purchase and then lease installed solar energy system to host users and two commercial customers accounted for 24%, 14%, 4% and 2% respectively, of our accounts receivable as of December 31, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P33_S4	The Company also has a potential concentration of supply risk in that during 2013 it purchased approximately 30% of the major components for its solar installations from a single supplier.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P33_S5	Sales to the Company s three largest customers for 2013 accounted for approximately 21%, 12% and 6%, respectively, of our total net revenue.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP requires the Company to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the accompanying financial statements and disclosures.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	Although these estimates are based on management s knowledge of current events and actions the Company may undertake in the future, actual results may be different from the estimates.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	The Company accounts for common stock warrants and put options in accordance with applicable accounting guidance provided in Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) ASC 480, Liabilities Distinguishing Liabilities from Equity, as either derivative liabilities or as equity instruments depending on the specific terms of the warrant agreement.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	The common stock warrants are accounted for as a liability due to a provision which allows for the warrant holder to require redemption, at the intrinsic value of the warrant, upon a change of control.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P35_S2	We classify these derivative liabilities on the condensed consolidated balance sheets as a long term liability, which is revalued at each balance sheet date subsequent to the initial issuance.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P35_S3	We use a Monte Carlo pricing model to value these derivative liabilities.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	The Monte Carlo pricing model, which is based, in part, upon unobservable inputs for which there is little or no market data, requires the Company to develop its own assumptions.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P36_S1	In building the Monte Carlo pricing model, the Company assumed a 15% probability of a change in control and used 20 nodes (See Note 3.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P36_S2	As a result, if factors change and different assumptions are used, the warrant liability and the change in estimated fair value could be materially different.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	Changes in the fair value of the warrants are reflected in the condensed consolidated balance sheet as change in fair value of warrant liability, with an offsetting non-cash entry recorded as interest.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	During 2013, net non-cash credits of approximately $2 million were recorded as interest income to reflect changes in fair value of outstanding warrants.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	In the event warrants are exercised or expire without being exercised, the fair value of the warrant liability is reduced by the number of warrants exercised or expired multiplied by the then fair value of the each warrant.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	Revolving Line of Credit and Term Loan Under a loan agreement, as amended, with Silicon Valley Bank ( SVB Loan ), the Company has a revolving line of credit that provides for advances not to exceed $6.5 million based upon a borrowing base of 75% of eligible accounts receivable.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P49_S1	All borrowings are collateralized by a security interest in substantially all of the Company s assets other than its interests in Alteris Project Financing Company LLC, and bear interest at the greater of the bank s prime rate or 4.00% plus 4.75%.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P49_S2	The interest rate accruing on borrowings during a Streamline Period (as defined in the SVB Loan) is the greater of the bank s prime rate or 4.00% plus 2.00%.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P49_S3	The original maturity date for the SVB Loan was October 30, 2012 and the maturity date was first extended to March 31, 2013 on October 30, 2012, then to September 30, 2013 on March 27, 2013, and then to September 30, 2014 on September 29, 2013.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	The line of credit has a facility fee of 0.5% per year of the average daily unused portion of the available line of credit during the applicable calendar quarter.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	We may reserve up to $500,000 for stand-by letters of credit under the line of credit.
1425565_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	The SVB Loan establishing the line of credit contains various covenants, including a covenant requiring compliance with a liquidity ratio.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P51_S2	The Company paid the final payment of $40,000 in conjunction with the Fifth Loan Modification Agreement.

1425565_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	Payable to Gaiam The Company is engaged in several related party transactions with Gaiam.
